meanings.def: to or at a lower place or position
examples: She jumped down off the chair.
He looked down at her.
We watched as the sun went down.
She bent down to pick up her glove.
Mary's not down yet (= she is still upstairs).
The baby can't keep any food down (= in her body).
I stuck the label down with sellotape.

meanings.def: from a standing position to a sitting or lying position
examples: Please sit down.
He had to go and lie down for a while.

meanings.def: at a lower level or rate
examples: Prices have gone down recently.
We're already two goals down (= the other team has two goals more).
Car crime in Oxford fell significantly last year.
Car crime fell by about a quarter over a 12-month period.
The number of stolen vehicles dropped from 1 013 to 780, a fall of 26 per cent.
According to this data, 780 vehicles were stolen, 26 per cent down on the previous year.
There was an 11 per cent drop in reported thefts from motor vehicles, from 1 971 to 1 737.
These figures show that, as far as car crime is concerned, the main trend is downwards.

meanings.def: used to show that the amount or strength of something is lower, or that there is less activity
examples: Turn the music down!
The class settled down and she began the lesson.

meanings.def: on paper; on a list
examples: Did you get that down?
I always write everything down.
Have you got me down for the trip?

meanings.def: reading from top to bottom, not from side to side
examples: I can't do 3 down.

meanings.def: to or in the south of a country
examples: They flew down to Texas.
Houses are more expensive down south.

meanings.def: from an important or famous place, especially a large city, to a smaller or less famous place
examples: We've got people from the head office coming down.
(British English) Her daughter's down from Oxford (= Oxford University) for the holidays.

meanings.def: used to show the limits in a range or an order
examples: Everyone will be there, from the Principal down.

meanings.def: having lost the amount of money mentioned
examples: At the end of the day we were £20 down.

meanings.def: if you pay an amount of money down, you pay that to start with, and the rest later
used to say how far you have got in a list of things you have to do
examples: Well, I've seen six apartments so far. That's six down and four to go!

meanings.def: to or at a local place such as a shop, pub, etc.
examples: I'm just going down to the post office.
I saw him down at the shops.

meanings.def: used to tell an animal or person to sit or lie
examples: ‘Down, boy!’ she laughed as the dog jumped up to greet her.

meanings.def: to be the responsibility of somebody
examples: It's down to you to check the door.

meanings.def: to be caused by a particular person or thing
examples: She claimed her problems were down to the media.

meanings.def: to have only a little money left
examples: I'm down to my last dollar.

meanings.def: to have or catch an illness
behaving in an unfair or aggressive way, especially because you want to win
examples: The candidate again got down and dirty with his rival.
The online campaign was getting down and dirty.

meanings.def: rude and making you feel shocked
examples: The singer got down and dirty at the club last night and made headlines again.
The singers are a down-and-dirty duo from Ohio.

meanings.def: during a long period of time
examples: Down through the years this town has seen many changes.

meanings.def: including every small part or detail of something
examples: She organized everything down to the last detail.

meanings.def: to or in Australia and/or New Zealand
used to say that you are opposed to something, or to a person
examples: The crowds chanted ‘Down with NATO!’

meanings.def: to be able to do something easily or well
examples: She's young and she hasn't really got it down yet.
The teacher gave us the music to the song and we had two weeks to get it down.
It looked easy once you got the system down.

meanings.def: a person who is determined or wants something very much will succeed

meanings.def: from a high or higher point on something to a lower one
examples: The stone rolled down the hill.
Tears ran down her face.
Her hair hung down her back to her waist.

meanings.def: along; towards the direction in which you are facing
examples: He lives just down the street.
Go down the road till you reach the traffic lights.
There's a bridge a mile down the river from here.

meanings.def: all through a period of time
examples: an exhibition of costumes down the ages (= from all periods of history)

meanings.def: to finish a drink or eat something quickly
examples: We downed our coffees and left.

meanings.def: to force somebody/something down to the ground
examples: to down a plane
Storms downed trees and power lines.

meanings.def: to touch the ball to the ground or touch your knee to the ground while holding the ball, so play has to stop
examples: He downed the ball inside the three-yard line.

meanings.def: to hit a ball into a hole
examples: Matthews downed a birdie putt at 15 to begin his comeback.

meanings.def: moving or directed downwards or away from a place
examples: The down escalator isn't working.
Click the down arrow.

meanings.def: sad or depressed
examples: I feel a bit down today.
You look a bit down. Is something the matter?
Don't let the weather get you down.

meanings.def: not working
examples: The system was down all morning.

meanings.def: to have no money because of a period of bad luck
